title-group.article-title: Feminism and cultural and religious diversity in Opzij: An analysis of the discourse of a Dutch feminist magazine

author-notes.corresp: Eve Midden, Utrecht University, Media and Culture Studies, Muntstraat 2A, Utrecht, 3512 EV, The Netherlands Email: E.Midden@uu.nl

abstract.p: Mainstream western feminism is generally known as secular. Women in this movement have fought religious dogmas and paternalistic gender patterns in religious texts and traditions. However, for many women all over the world religion is also an important part of their lives. Some of them try to combine their religious beliefs and feminist ideals. For a long time, their discussions remained at the margins, but in the last few years, ‘mainstream’ feminists are forced to rethink their standpoint about religion. Many have chosen a critical approach towards the relationship between religion and emancipation, but others express the need to take into account differences between women in the definition of feminism and emancipation. This article analyses a popular Dutch feminist magazine and how it defines feminism in relation to religion and culture. The article undertakes an in-depth analysis of how the notions of religion, culture and feminism are interpreted and discussed in the Dutch feminist magazine Opzij. The concepts of experience, solidarity, emancipation and difference are central in the investigation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: It was long assumed that both multiculturalism and feminism are connected to progressive movements and hence have comparable and compatible goals. However, both in academia and in popular media the critique on multiculturalism has grown and is often accompanied with arguments related to gender equality and/or feminism. In the Netherlands, Ayaan Hirsi Ali1 has been an important actor in the debates about multiculturalism in general, and Islam specifically. One of her main arguments is that Islamic sexual morality keeps Muslim men, women and children in a ‘virgin cage’, which prevents them from adapting their religion to western values such as individualism and freedom (Ali, 2004). But also the Dutch politician Geert Wilders is known for his extremely critical views on multiculturalism, integration and Islam and references to gender equality in his arguments. In September 2009 for example, he proposed to introduce a ‘headscarf tax’.2 He argued that as women who wear a headscarf might be considered to pollute the public sphere in the Netherlands, they should pay for a permit to wear the headscarf in the Netherlands. This extreme proposal led to a heated debate in the Netherlands, also because the words he used to introduce his ideas about the headscarf were considered highly offensive.3

Besides these politicians, feminists also have been critical about the relationship between religious and cultural diversity and feminism. Cisca Dresselhuys, for example, is well known for her ideas about the influence of religion on women’s lives and especially for her famous remark about the incompatibility of the headscarf and feminism.4 Such arguments raise many questions about possible conceptualizations of equality, subjectivity, emancipation and freedom. Feminism has a long history of thinking about difference, but the current debates seem to force feminists to rethink these with more urgency and adjust them to renewed political contexts. In this article I analyse how the feminist popular Dutch magazine Opzij has defined feminism and feminist struggles in relation to cultural and religious diversity. Opzij is the most long-standing and influential feminist monthly in the Netherlands and it represents the dominant approach to feminism. Furthermore, through its many interviews with politicians and opinion leaders, it also forms a bridge between feminist views and the broader public debate.

My own commitment to writing this article originates from a certain void in feminist thinking and vocabulary when it comes to the relationship between cultural and religious diversity and feminism. I am a white, non-religious feminist, but I do not adhere to the politics of secular feminists who simply condemn other women’s faiths and cultures as problematic. On the other hand, I find it difficult to understand that some women do not fight against patriarchal traditions which are part of their culture or religion. Therefore, I want to develop the vocabulary and analytical tools to better understand the complexity of the relationship between culture, religion and feminism, and to develop more nuanced perspectives towards it.

The main aims of the article are to enhance our understanding of the arguments and disagreements in the feminist discourse of Opzij and eventually to critically rethink the relationship between feminism and culture and religion as discussed in many European countries, of which the Netherlands is just one example. In that sense, the instruments that I employ to investigate and rethink the relationship between these concepts are very relevant for other countries as well. Moreover, the particular aspects of the Dutch discourse make it an excellent learning case. Since the murders of Pim Fortuyn and Theo van Gogh, multiculturalism in general, and Islam specifically, has been high on the political agenda. A climate arose in which so-called ‘political correctness’ was left behind and it was argued that people should be able to say anything they want about other groups in society. Due to the abandonment of ‘political correctness’, we are faced with an almost unfiltered debate.

sec.title: Opzij: An introduction
sec.p: Opzij is a monthly magazine in the Netherlands in which various issues related to women, emancipation and feminism (such as work, family life and politics) are discussed.5 It is also the most long-standing and influential feminist monthly in the Netherlands. It started as a radical and activist magazine, but changed over time into a more mainstream feminist magazine. The total circulation of the magazine is 85,000 and the readers are mostly well-educated, well-off women, between the ages of 25 and 49. Remarkably, the magazine’s website does not say anything about the ethnicity of its readers.

Since September 2008, Margiet van der Linden has been the editor-in-chief of Opzij. She is the successor to Cisca Dresselhuys, who held this position from 1981 to 2008. Van der Linden has changed Opzij considerably. She states that the most important transformation is that the magazine has become more open to diversity. One such example is the enlisting of Moroccan-Dutch columnist Nora Kasrioui, who writes about the emancipation of ‘allochtonous’ girls. These changes to Opzij are not the subject of this article, however; the sample for the analysis herein was deliberately selected from the years 2004–2007 when Cisca Dresselhuys was still the editor-in-chief. The reason for this is that I first of all found it important to gain more knowledge about the different discourses on cultural and religious diversity and feminism in the years that these issues were at the top of the political agenda. Second, these ‘earlier years’ cover an important strand in the discussions about this subject that needs to be investigated further. Hence, by starting from the critical views of the Opzij editors in the years 2004–2007, this article aims to develop a better understanding of the relationship between religion, culture and feminism. The idea behind this is that a close analysis of this specific aspect of the discourse will give us more insight into the different interpretations of feminism and could be a starting point for a redefinition of the relationship between cultural and religious diversity and feminism in a more nuanced, dynamic and positive manner. In that context I would like to emphasize that this article does not aim to present an overview of the definitions of multiculturalism and feminism in Opzij, but rather wants to contribute to current debates about feminism and multiculturalism by closely analysing the different arguments about these subject in a very specific context. Hence, while it would be possible to find statements in Opzij (under the current editor-in-chief) with different perspectives on feminism and religion, this article focuses purposely on another period of Opzij, with more sceptical views about these subjects.

sec.title: Feminism and cultural and religious diversity
sec.p: As I mentioned in the introduction, feminism and multiculturalism have for the last two decades regularly been described as incompatible. In her famous essay ‘Is multiculturalism bad for women’, Susan Moller Okin (1999) for instance argues that if we agree that women should not be disadvantaged because of their sex, then we should not accept group rights that permit oppressive practices. According to Okin, cultures and religions are suffused with practices and ideologies concerning gender, and most cultures facilitate control over women in various ways. Okin published her essay together with about a dozen responding papers and was both criticized and applauded by other scholars. Her claims led to a complex and important debate.

In the Netherlands, sociologist Sawitri Saharso responded with a counter essay, called ‘Multiculturalism and feminism’. Saharso claims that multiculturalism and feminism might not always be easily compatible, but that they are certainly not incompatible either (Saharso, 2000). They can be friends, she says, even though it is a friendship that needs to be worked on. According to Saharso there are two rather remarkable things about the (Dutch) debates on multiculturalism. First of all, very often, Dutch culture is set against ‘the’ cultures of foreigners. Second, most of the discussions on tolerance refer to gender relations. Saharso argues that in order to draw a line regarding tolerance towards others cultures, the defenders of Dutch culture often use ‘women’s issues’.

This connects to the work of Baukje Prins, who states that the harsh discussions about multiculturalism and Islam in the Netherlands show that since the 1990s a new public discourse has arisen (Prins, 2002). According to Prins, this ‘neo-realist’ genre can be recognized by four main characteristics: authors or speakers in this discourse present themselves as persons ‘who dare to face the facts’ and openly discuss what is really happening; they believe themselves to be representing ‘normal people’; they argue that having ‘a sense of reality’ is an important part of the Dutch national identity; and finally, neo-realists can be recognized by their aversion to the political left. Moreover, an essential element of the neo-realist discourse is the importance of emancipation in these debates. Even though none of the neo-realists seem to have shown any interest in feminism or women’s rights before, they now use gender relations to define their own identity as opposite to the ‘Other’. An example of this would be how they often claim to rescue or save migrant women from their traditional lives and conservative men (Prins, 2002).

Also Duits and Van Zoonen emphasize that ‘girls’ bodies have become the metonymic location for many of the social and cultural struggles in Western European immigration societies’ (Duits and Van Zoonen, 2006); even though the voices of the girls involved are hardly ever heard in this context, as their choices are mainly articulated in terms of their sexuality and lack of agency. By showing the compatibilities between the Dutch discourses on porno-chic and Muslims women’s headscarves, Duits and Van Zoonen also make it very clear how these issues have connected ‘western conservatism with radical feminism, fundamentalist Islam, traditional Christianity, liberal feminism and all other ideologies and actors that would support bans on women’s garments’ (Duits and Van Zoonen, 2006: 114). In this article, the main concepts in these debates are rethought in order to produce an alternative perspective.

sec.title: Sample and method of analysis
sec.p: The material I used to analyse Opzij covers a period of time in which the relationship between cultural and religious diversity and feminism was a much-discussed subject: July 2004–July 2007. It includes very important moments related to the topic, such as the first broadcast (on Dutch national television) of Ayaan Hirsi Ali’s film Submission (August 2004), the murder of the director of this film, Theo van Gogh (November 2004), and the case around the passport of Ali and her departure to the USA (May 2006). Ayaan Hirsi Ali is generally seen as the dominant factor in the Dutch debates about culture, religion and feminism (or gender equality), so her input and these events are also of great importance for this article.

In order to find all the articles in Opzij (from July 2004 to July 2007)6 that deal with culture and religion, I chose a combination of search terms that refer both to the issue in general (multiculturalism, religion, integration, ‘allochtonous’ and traditions) and to specific events or themes that have been important in the Dutch debates about culture and diversity (Islam, burqa, Muslim women and Ayaan Hirsi Ali).7 This resulted in a total of 164 articles, of which 56 were actually relevant to this research project. Articles were regarded as irrelevant if they only mentioned one of the search terms in passing, and did not actually discuss the subject. Finally, there were a number (20) of short articles and news items which were relevant but were excluded from the analysis because of their short length and lack of argumentation. This brings the total number of articles for the analysis to 36. I acknowledge that this is a rather small sample, which does not lend itself for any generalizations. It is however very appropriate for the in-depth analysis in this article, which aims to explore and rethink the relationship between religious and cultural diversity and feminism.

For this article the main approach is critical discourse analysis (CDA), following especially the work of Norman Fairclough (2001). I have chosen to focus on the work of Norman Fairclough regarding CDA because power and power relations are central in his work. After a preliminary analysis of the sample, it turned out that the articles in Opzij could not simply be divided on the basis of their arguments (positive or negative) regarding the relationship between cultural and religious diversity and feminism. In fact, only a small part of the sample explicitly discussed this relationship and presented either a pessimistic or optimistic argument about it. In the other articles, only a specific facet of this relationship was focused upon. This focus was often a dilemma, a problem to be resolved or something that needed to be changed, according to the author or interviewee. Definitions of culture, religion, multiculturalism, feminism and their relationship were taken for granted and hence not further investigated.

The fact that most articles did not have an explicit argument on the relationship between cultural and religious diversity and feminism (but rather make a statement about a related topic, based on a certain, often not explained, interpretation of this relationship) was not only an important first conclusion of the preliminary investigation of Opzij, but also a complicating factor for further analysis of the sample. Hence, not only explicit arguments about culture, religion and feminism turned out to be relevant for the research, but also much more implicit ones. In order to get a better understanding of the Opzij discourse, I focused on two basic questions from discourse analysis. First of all, who or what is the object of the article/statement? Or, more concretely, who or what needs to change according to the author or interviewee? The second question was: who or what is considered as the problem and who or what as the solution? The answers to these questions resulted in a rich overview of the arguments in the Opzij articles.

After analysing the sample with the first question, six categories or answers could be distinguished: feminism (or feminists), Muslim women, Islam (or Muslim traditions), Dutch society (or government), the style of debating and finally the relationship between multiculturalism and feminism. Of course one could think of possible other facets of this relationship but they could not be found as such in Opzij. This article focuses on the first two categories of the sample: feminism (feminist standpoints and feminist solidarity) and Muslim women (who counts as feminist? mechanisms of in/exclusion), concluding with a critical investigation of the dynamics among these categories in different Opzij articles.8 One consequence of this is that this article pays disproportional attention to Islam, not because I confuse cultural and religious diversity with Islam, but because the sample mainly concentrates on this specific group.

sec.title: Feminist standpoints
sec.p: In her two columns around the issue of how feminism should deal with multiculturalism, Jolande Withuis puts forward two main problems; the first is ‘historical’ and the second is about contemporary feminists in the field of gender studies.

In ‘Strijdbaar en superieur’ (‘Warrior like and superior’) Withuis writes about the struggle of a ‘first wave’ feminist and shows why feminists should defend their own struggles, instead of asking ‘average women’ what they want. In 1917, 43,000 Christian women signed the petition ‘do not give us the right to vote’ (Withuis, 2006), nevertheless, Withuis argues, nobody would now dare to say that feminists at that time should have changed their views on voting. According to Withuis:

disp-quote.p: This historical fact teaches us . . . that religions can change . . . ; it teaches us that Christianity is not less hostile to women than Islam is. Furthermore, it reminds us that also the pioneers of the first wave sometimes did not get support from the women whose interests they defended. (Withuis, 2006,; my translation)

sec.p: Hence, according to Withuis, feminists do not need the approval of all women in their struggles. In some cases they should just fight for what they think is right. The question that comes to mind here is: when is a female argument a feminist one? Or, which standpoints count as feminist? Withuis argues that feminists do not need the approval of all women, but who says that feminists should? It seems that this author tries to exclude her opponents from the discussions by referring to extreme arguments. Unfortunately this rules out the option of a possible fruitful debate about standpoint theory.

In ‘Meninkjes’ (‘Little opinions’) Withuis expands on the issue of ‘approval’. The problem, in her view, is that researchers constantly refer to the fact that we should listen to the opinions of Muslim women, instead of criticizing certain categories, such as Muslims and non-Muslims. The argument she gives for this statement is that oppressed people are not always open to liberation:

disp-quote.p: If someone argues that ‘Muslim women want to wear a headscarf’, I not only see the veiled 10 year olds, but also Aafke Komter’s De macht van de vanzelfsprekendheid (The Power of the Self Evident). After this analysis of invisible power differences in marriages, the phrase ‘what they want themselves’ is an empty slogan. Komter shows that something as simple as ‘to want something yourself’ does not exist: the least powerful people give shape to their desires through those of the powerful and experience those as their own. (Withuis, 2005; my translation)

sec.p: According to Withuis, it is meaningless to think about ‘what women themselves’ want, because there is no such thing as ‘wanting yourself’. I must agree with her that people are shaped by the society they live in. The question is, however, whether Withuis is indeed criticizing the concept of autonomy and starting a (legitimate) discussion or whether she is using the argument to claim that certain people cannot judge their own decisions. It is difficult to answer this question based on these two quotes only, but it does appear that she is not referring to her own ability to make decisions in these quotes. I elaborate on this in the next sections, in which the discrepancy between ‘feminists’ and ‘Muslim women’ comes even more to the surface. The implicit reference in this quote is to false consciousness, or the idea that people (in this case Muslim women) might believe that they want something, but in practice do not realize that they have come to believe this, through the influence of an oppressive power. Many feminists have criticized this concept,9 my arguments against it in the context of this particular quote are the following. First of all, it is often used to depict a particular group (namely Muslim women). Hence, there are already unequal power relations at play when the concept of false consciousness is utilized. Second, the concept of false consciousness does not help us to better understand the issues at stake here. Instead of investigating the arguments, experiences and strategies of different women and evaluating what makes a feminist standpoint, denouncing other opinions as false puts the issues at stake aside.

To summarize, Withuis argues that discussions about religion and culture too often end up in statements from certain feminists about the experiences and opinions of the women who live in these communities. She believes that this is not the right approach for feminists. First of all, she says, we have historical examples that show that sometimes some women just do not know what is best for them, and second, gender theorists have shown that women can think they want something, without realizing they might have been influenced by more powerful others.

The issues of experience and feminist standpoints are also discussed in a group interview article with 14 experts. In this article, a group of gender and diversity experts (researchers, politicians and women who work for relevant NGOs) talk about how feminism should deal with cultural and religious differences. The most important aspect of the discussion is the question: should (Dutch, secular) feminists hold on to their ideas about equality and justice or should they be more open to different interpretations and ask Muslim women what they want? Contrary to Withuis, many of these experts say that we should talk to Muslim women, instead of about them.10 The various answers in the interviews, however, show that the question of feminist standpoints is not just about listening or not listening to Muslim women (as Withuis seems to argue), but rather about whose experiences should count as feminist. The division between ‘feminists’ and ‘Muslim women’ continues to play an important role in most Opzij articles/statements.

Local politician Fatima Elatik believes that feminists should respect the fact that there are different ways to achieve emancipation. She further argues that the strength of Muslim women is not sufficiently acknowledged:

disp-quote.p: Muslim women want to become emancipated in their own way, with respect for their background and religious traditions and by keeping the dialogue with their family. We have to facilitate that. (Elatik, 2005, cited in Dresselhuys, 2005; my translation)

sec.p: Elatik explicitly argues that there are different ways of achieving emancipation, implicitly however, she also points out that Muslim women’s experiences and standpoints should be taken into account in feminist analyses or struggles. Through these words, Elatik goes beyond the framework of feminists that either need or do not need approval, as presented by Jolande Withuis. The issue, according to Elatik, is not about approval, but about defining emancipation. However, judging from the quote above, the question related to the division between ‘Muslim women’ and ‘feminists’ remains. Who is the ‘we’ she is referring to in the last sentence of the quote? It seems that Elatik criticizes feminists who judge Muslim women for having a different perspective on emancipation, but she does not deconstruct the framework and power relations behind this.

Marli Huijer argues that Dutch feminists ‘should not act like big sisters’. She does not make a division between Muslim women and feminists, but explicitly talks about different forms of feminism. Dutch feminists, she argues:

disp-quote.p: . . . can contribute by not regarding these women as more oppressed, but as women whose own feminism needs support. (Huijer, 2005, cited in Dresselhuys, 2005; my translation)

sec.p: Van Zoonen also emphasizes the importance of supporting the struggles of these women:

disp-quote.p: I get so sick of all these little opinions and do not understand where Dutch people get their so called expertise about Islam and Muslim women from. I do not have this expertise and would rather have the women who are trying to combine emancipation and Islam to speak for themselves. (Van Zoonen, 2005, cited in Dresselhuys, 2005; my translation)

sec.p: In the above quotes, the interviewees argue for a different approach towards feminism. They plead for cooperation between different women, but frame the issue rather differently to Withuis. They propose that Dutch or secular feminists support Muslim feminists and recognize their struggles and choices. Hence, they aim to acknowledge different interpretations of emancipation and feminism. In other words, they want to work together with women who share similar goals, even though they might have different approaches to achieve these goals. Withuis, on the other hand, does not want feminists to debate their ideals with women who are not interested in emancipation. While Withuis talks about whom we should not listen to, Huijer and Van Zoonen talk about who we should listen to.

Van Zoonen and Huijer start from multiple interpretations of feminism and aim to achieve cooperation between women, while acknowledging differences. Withuis, on the other hand, frames the discussion rather differently; she starts from the problem: how should feminists respond to women who do not want to be emancipated? Feminists, according to Withuis, should not ask these women what they want, but fight the oppression and deconstruct certain categories. In my view, Huijer and Van Zoonen do not necessarily dispute this when they say that feminists should support the struggles of Muslim women.

Here lies the connection to the many discussions among feminists about standpoint theory. Withuis seems to fight against a rather essentialist and fixed interpretation of standpoint theory. According to her, not all women can produce better knowledge because they are in a marginalized position. On the contrary, she believes that oppression can blind people from a critical view. Huijer and Van Zoonen, however, defend a rather different, much more dynamic and collective perspective on standpoint theory. They not only take into account the power differences (and oppression) between men and women, but also between women. Furthermore, they do not start from any marginalized woman’s position, but from those who have developed oppositional consciousness. This suggests that if we want to theorize this issue further in a productive way, we should not allow ourselves to get stuck in sentences like ‘should we or should we not listen to Muslim women’, but instead think about how we can use experience as a basis for feminist standpoints.

sec.title: Feminist solidarity
sec.p: In the previous section, the problems related to feminists’ responses to multiculturalism (or actually Islam) were discussed. I pointed out that many of the statements deal with different aspects of this issue, without really engaging in a single and well-defined debate. In the following, I move the focus of attention from feminist standpoints to feminist solidarity. Many of the articles in Opzij focused on the issue of solidarity. It seems again, though, that there is no clear definition of the disagreement. The discussion is framed as if there is a difference of opinion between those who aim for solidarity between women and those who do not. Yet, when we take a closer look at the statements it appears that most (if not all) authors aim for more solidarity. Hence, the actual debate is about the right interpretations of solidarity.
Jolande Withuis talks about solidarity using the case of Ayaan Hirsi Ali. In her view, feminists need to show their solidarity with this politician:

disp-quote.p: Where are the educated feminists who support (or if necessary refute) Ayaan with fundamental analyses and usable research results? When do ‘the girlfriends’ of Ayaan Hirsi Ali turn up alongside ‘the friends’? . . . Why are professors and students from women’s studies not protesting at the parliament buildings since 2 November: we are not leaving until she returns? . . . A black refugee is threatened with death because of her feminist political opinion. (Withuis, 2005; my translation)

sec.p: Judging from this quote, Withuis believes there is a lack of solidarity among feminists for Hirsi Ali. Because Hirsi Ali is threatened as a black feminist, feminists should support her. This view clearly differs from most remarks that were made in the group interview article. Marli Huijer for instance, argues that:

disp-quote.p: Solidarity with Muslim women starts with informing ourselves of the long tradition of (pan-) Arabic feminism, with interest in the lives and stories of Muslim women and with allowing and facilitating these women’s own ideas in public space. . . . Dutch feminists can contribute to that by not seeing Muslim women beforehand as more oppressed, but as women whose feminism deserves support. (Huijer, 2005, cited in Dresselhuys, 2005; my translation)

sec.p: Especially this last quote shows how close the connection is between the discussions on feminist standpoints and on feminist solidarity. Those who are considered to have proper feminist standpoints are also regarded as deserving of feminist solidarity. The different views on equality and difference are related to this. The writers in Opzij largely base their judgement regarding feminist standpoints on definitions of equality. Those who struggle for equality through sameness aim for feminist standpoints that do this, too, and vice versa. Hence, Withuis supports Ayaan Hirsi Ali and her struggle for equality through sameness; Huijer connects to Muslim feminists, who fight for equality through difference. Both authors detect a lack of solidarity among feminists, but do not recognize the different starting points of their struggles. As becomes clear from this analysis, there is solidarity among feminists, but only between those feminists who share the same vision on equality.

sec.title: Who counts as feminist? Mechanism of in/exclusion
sec.p: In the previous paragraphs I discussed the discourse in Opzij on feminism, more specifically on feminist standpoints and solidarity. When does a female standpoint count as a feminist one and when should feminists show their solidarity with other women? This section focuses on the articles about Muslim women. By scrutinizing the discourse about Muslim women in Opzij, it becomes clear how they are separated from ‘feminists’ and ‘feminism’.

The first thing to be noted about the articles on Muslim women is that they are written from a rather different perspective than those on feminism and feminists. In most of the articles of the latter category there was often an explicit statement to be found on the problems and solutions related to the connection between multiculturalism and feminism. In the articles on Muslim women, on the other hand, these statements are much more implicit. I believe that this is connected to the different aims of these pieces. The articles on ‘feminism’ share a commitment to theorize feminism, and as mentioned above, the discussions were mostly about feminist standpoints. The articles that focus on Muslim women do not correspond to that goal; they do not theorize how Muslim women see feminism or how to be a Muslim feminist in a western country. Instead, they are centred on one particular question: why do women choose to live according to (strict) Islamic customs? The number of articles on feminism and Muslim women is too small to allow us to draw strong conclusions, but it is worth noting that Opzij has no articles that theorize how, for instance, feminism and Islam can/cannot be combined. I would like to argue that this is connected to the conceptualization of feminism in Opzij. Instead of discussing different interpretations of feminism, such as Muslim feminism and secular feminism, Opzij’s articles either talk about how feminists should deal with difference or about the decisions of Muslim women. In this way, it seems they position (secular/white) feminists on one side and Muslim women on the other. In other words: there are feminists and there are Muslim women.
The headscarf is an important theme in Opzij and in many articles and interviews there is some sort of reference to it.

In 2006, Bochhah interviewed six women on the issue of the headscarf. Her article discusses why Muslim women decide to wear a headscarf. The women interviewed mention a broad range of reasons: (1) rebellion/resistance, (2) religion, (3) identity/definition of the self and (4) family/community. Most of their reasons are related to their self-image or identity: I feel prettier when I wear one, I feel more secure, it reminds me of my Muslim identity, or it makes me feel more conscious of my behaviour. Then there are the religious reasons for wearing a headscarf: I do it out of love for the Prophet, it makes my faith complete, or it is a command and I like living according to the rules of the Qu’ran. Finally, there are the arguments related to the (expectations of) family or community: I get more respect from Moroccan boys, my family appreciates it that I wear a headscarf, or I want to show people that I am a good Muslim.

The statements about the headscarf are very descriptive: Opzij does not explicitly write about what Muslim women should or should not do, as it does for feminists. Instead the magazine is exploring why Muslim women do certain things. This could mean that the editors find these women’s choices problematic, but they could also be trying to make these women’s choices seen more acceptable for feminists. In any case, Opzij is trying to understand these women and their choices, which suggests a distance between the Opzij editors (or their audience) and Muslim women. I believe that this shows that the editors of Opzij focus on a white or non-Muslim audience. Hence, they are not trying to raise understanding for Muslim women among Muslim women.

In the article ‘De lokroep van de Islam’ (‘The call of Islam’), psychiatrist Carla Rus investigates why young women (especially ‘autochtonous’ Dutch women who decide to convert) are attracted to Islam. The question she wants to answer is:

disp-quote.p: Which young women voluntarily give up the rights and freedoms that my generation of women have obtained during the second wave with so much pain? (Rus, 2006; my translation)

sec.p: Two aspects of this question stand out. First of all, the author assumes that these women are giving up rights when they are converting to Islam. One might wonder whether this is necessarily the case or, in fact, whether these women might not mind giving up certain liberal rights. Authors such as Saba Mahmood (2005) have shown that not all women want liberal freedom; some women actually choose to submit to God and/or possible patriarchal religious traditions. Rus approaches this issue as a matter of false consciousness: why do people do things that are not in their best interest? This means that she is not really asking an open ‘why’ question. Or to put it more bluntly, she seems to judge these women’s choices already in her question, instead of being open to understand them better.

Second, there is a generational aspect in the question. The women who become Muslim are not just giving up any rights, but the rights that women from Rus’s generation have fought for. This is where the pain seems to lie. I believe that this could be an important aspect of the discussions about multiculturalism and feminism that needs further investigation. At first sight, the differences between feminist generations might not be connected to multiculturalism, but we need to ask why many of the feminists from the second wave generation are now so fiercely criticizing Islam. The answer could be found in the following quote:

disp-quote.p: For me as an ex-Reformed person, who has wrested from an external authority and had learned to trust her own authority, this is shocking to read. These women are actually saying that they do not know what to do in life without a religious leader and that they do not trust themselves enough when it comes to morals. (Rus, 2006; my translation)

sec.p: Hence, Rus herself has struggled against external authorities and cannot imagine why other women would actually desire this. From her perspective every woman would choose to be free (from authorities) if she could.

In the first instance, this article on conversion seems comparable to those on the headscarf, but the final argument of this piece is considerably different. The authors cited earlier only tried to understand Muslim women who decide to wear the headscarf. In other words, there was no clear normative statement to be found. Rus, on the other hand, is providing the reader explicitly with her opinion on this issue. Most arguments for conversion are followed by a statement of the author in which she explains why such arguments are problematic in her view. Hence, in this case, the author is trying to understand these women’s choices and at the same time thinks about how to change them. This is confirmed by her conclusion, in which she says:

disp-quote.p: There is no use in fighting these new Islamic Dutch girls; the history of Christianity teaches us that faith grows when it is oppressed. They should be tempted back via good examples: women with self-esteem who help others out of an inner civilisation, without wanting anything back for it – not even afterwards in paradise. (Rus, 2006; my translation)

sec.p: Note that there lies a long history behind the words Rus is using. For example during the first wave of feminism, white, bourgeois feminists tried to emphasize their importance for the nation (and hence the need for civil rights) by arguing that they needed to help Others. They created a task for themselves by defining social issues as other people’s problems. This way they managed to transfer the boundaries of the nation; they included themselves, by creating new second range citizens, such as women from the colonies (see, for instance, Waaldijk, 1999). Of course we cannot easily apply the strategies of certain first wave feminists to the remarks of Carla Rus, but it is remarkable that the concept of ‘helping others’ remains recurrent in feminism. The similarities (and differences) between these approaches to feminism need further investigation.

sec.title: Rethinking feminist standpoints and experience
sec.p: The discussions in Opzij as discussed in the previous sections connect to a long history of feminist thinking on standpoint theory and situated knowledges. Both theories have taught us that location can influence our views on certain issues. The main difference is that standpoint theory starts from the normative notion that certain positions provide better grounds for knowledge production (Harding, 1991), while the theory of ‘situated knowledges’ demonstrates that all standpoints provide partial views, for which we have to be accountable (Haraway, 1991).

If we apply standpoint theory and situated knowledges to this discussion, we see that both will help us in rethinking the relationship between culture, religion and feminism from a more critical perspective than Opzij does. Standpoint theory tells us why we need a view from below, and should take the experiences of women from minority cultures into account. But standpoint theory is not merely about women’s experiences; these are just a point of departure, a ground for ‘knowledge-claims’ (Bracke, 2004). In order to develop a standpoint, one needs to combine social location with political analysis. When we approach standpoint theory in such a manner, it becomes obvious why it is important that the voices from Islamic feminists should be taken into account in feminist research and theory. These women have transformed their experiences (from below) into standpoints, through their political projects. Of course, the question of which standpoints are ‘proper’ standpoints is not always easy to answer and obviously still leads to much discussion between feminists.

Where Bracke starts from a political interpretation of standpoint theory to make feminist thinking more complex, one could also turn to the concept of situated knowledges. Haraway emphasizes the construction of identities much more explicitly than Harding does and plays with identities and boundaries (where for Harding these are much more static). Prins (1997) argues that the Dutch discourse on ethnic minorities and multiculturalism is a good case for exploring the concept of situated knowledges, because it is a discourse in which many ‘non-innocent’ positions are put forward, and because the relations between marginal and dominant groups in society are at stake. This is also reflected in the discourse of Opzij where white, secular women seem to judge the positions of religious women, without critically investigating their own.

I would like to argue that both concepts are important in feminist research, but they relate to different angles of the debate about culture, religion and feminism. Hence, if we want to rethink statements about the so-called tensions between these concepts, one could argue that minority women also fight for equality, albeit it in another way and, for example, from within their community. Another argument, however, would be that some women might not want the equality or freedom that, for example, Ayaan Hirsi Ali stands for. These different lines of reasoning are connected to different theoretical frameworks. I would like to argue that standpoint theory would be an important instrument in the first and that situated knowledges provides us with an entry to the latter. In my view, a redefinition of the relationship between culture, religion and feminism needs to take into account both of these classical feminist concepts and apply them to current debates (e.g. about religion and feminism) to develop more inclusive interpretations of feminism.

Moreover, the current debates about agency and subjectivity teach us much about how to think differently about feminism and religion. Saba Mahmood (2005), for example, states that if feminists really want to understand the lives, experiences and strategies of all women, we have to be open to the possibility that we can learn from other women and maybe even change our political views accordingly. Therefore, according to Mahmood, feminists have to separate their analytical and prescriptive work (Mahmood, 2005). Hence, we should not try to define beforehand whether a certain experience is a good standpoint or not, but first try to understand it and discuss the political consequences afterwards. In order to be able to do this, Mahmood argues, feminists have to rethink their conceptualization of agency. Most feminist thinking is primarily liberatory and agency in this context is described as a model of subordination and subversion. Mahmood argues that this attachment of agency to progressive politics is problematic. If, she says, there are different ways to change the world depending on social, political and historical contexts, then the meaning of agency should not be fixed in advance.

I agree with Mahmood that feminists need more open analytical tools in order to research these topics. However, I also think that, besides opening up the concept, the discussions about cultural and religious diversity and feminism would benefit from a conception of subjectivity that combines a certain form of openness with a road to change. I believe that the work of Rosi Braidotti provides us with such a combination (Braidotti, 2008). While arguing that normative secularism is too closely connected to Islamophobia, she calls for a more nuanced analysis of the relations between feminism and religion/spirituality. She emphasizes the long history of feminism and spirituality (think of the work of Audre Lorde or Luce Irigaray) and the importance of recognizing this. The interesting aspect of Braidotti’s definition of subjectivity is that she aims to keep subjectivity ‘political’ without letting it become negative or fixed. This means that her interpretation of subjectivity is not about producing radical counter-subjectivities, but rather about daily practices and negotiations within dominant norms:

disp-quote.p: Political subjectivity or agency therefore consists of multiple micro-political practices of daily activism or interventions in and on the world we inhabit for ourselves and our future generations. (Braidotti, 2008: 16)

sec.p: Hence, by applying these refreshing interpretations of agency and subjectivity and applying more classical feminist conceptions of standpoint theory and situated knowledges, it becomes possible to analyse the lives and experiences of religious women or women from minority cultures differently. Rather than evaluating their activities and choices within the limited framework of subordination versus liberation or ‘should we listen to them or not’, more nuanced perspectives can be developed, with attention to daily negotiations or alternative perspectives on equality and liberty.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article I have analysed three years of Opzij articles on the relationship between feminism and multiculturalism. Comparing the articles in the preceding sections on ‘Muslim women’ and those on ‘feminists’, I would like to argue that even though Muslim women’s issues are discussed in Opzij, these women are not really involved in the discussions about feminism. In the articles about Muslim women, choices are evaluated from a universal view on feminism. Feminism, in these cases, is approached as something quite fixed. For instance, there were no articles in which authors discussed whether and how feminism and Islam could be combined. Also in the section on feminists, I could not find such debates. Furthermore, in the pieces on feminism there was no discussion about why (white) feminists do certain things. Thus, Muslim women’s choices are investigated, while those of (white) feminists are not. Note though that white (allochtonous) women who decide to convert to Islam are investigated. They seem to fall in-between the applied categories. Second, feminists discuss what feminism is or should be, but not how it could be combined with religion. In other words, only the boundaries of feminism are debated, not the basics.

Another point that is of importance is the use and abuse of standpoint theories. In my view, one of the main disagreements revolves around the question: who can decide what a feminist standpoint is, or is not? On many occasions, remarks are found that refer either to a lack or to a surplus of contact with certain groups of women. Can feminists develop general ideas about what feminism is, or should they be more open to the experiences and opinions of women? The essential question here is, when we talk about experience, whose experience do we mean? Those who want to take experiences into account seem to refer to a specific, political, interpretation of standpoint theory. They do not propose to ask ‘average’ women what they think of certain issues. Instead, they propose working more closely with Muslim feminists. The opponents of this approach on the other hand, often mention a much more individual interpretation of ‘taking women’s experiences into account’.

This media analysis showed that one of the main points of discussion in Opzij was who is included in the feminist ‘us’ and who is not. The key concepts in these discussions were experience and solidarity. I would like to argue that feminism can be defined in a more inclusive way, but then it needs to take into account the critical standpoints that Muslim women have developed, as well as the critical perspectives on agency and subjectivity, such as proposed by authors like Rosi Braidotti and Saba Mahmood. Finally, they need to acknowledge differences between women, as well as the possibilities of different ideas about what emancipation means.

Ayaan Hirsi Ali is a politician, opinion maker and writer, who came to the Netherlands as a refugee from Somalia in 1992. In 2002, she became a member of the (conservative) liberal party VVD, in this period she also started to publish her ideas on Islam and women. In the summer of 2004, Ali’s film Submission was first shown. Only months later, the director of the film, Theo van Gogh, was killed in the centre of Amsterdam. The film is generally seen as the direct reason for this political murder. In May 2006, Ali reached world headlines again because of a discussion about her asylum. A Dutch television documentary showed that she had lied about her name, age and her escape to the Netherlands. The Minister of Integration and Immigration soon announced that these lies made Ali’s passport invalid. A month later, the minister changed her decision and said that Ali could keep her passport, because apparently she was allowed to use the name Ali according to Somalian law. A few days later the government collapsed because one of the coalition’s parties withdrew its support following these events. Ayaan Hirsi Ali left the country anyhow, to start a new career in Washington.

Rather than the regular word for head (hoofd) he used the word that only refers to the heads of animals (kop). Moreover, he did not talk about scarves, but about vodden, which could be translated as a rag or cleaning cloth.

Cisca Dresselhuys was editor-in-chief of Opzij from 1981 until 2008. In the years Cisca Dresselhuys held this position, she was an important, well-known figure who represented the magazine in many public discussions. She also regularly made the headlines herself with her often explicit and controversial statements. One of the most famous of these is the remark she made in the daily newspaper de Volkskrant: ‘In a coffee house I don’t endure sexism; circumcision is a taboo for me and editors with a headscarf are not welcome at Opzij’ (Dresselhuys, 2001, cited in Van Gelder and Schottelndreier, 2001). This comment lead to a heated debate about feminism and religion and made Dresselhuys known for her critical perspective on religion in general, and Islam specifically.
The information in this section about the history and readers of Opzij comes from the website of the magazine: www.opzij.nl.
The search was conducted electronically, through the search engine of Lexis Nexis.
The exact words I used are (in Dutch): multiculturalisme, religie, integratie, allochtonen, tradities, Islam, Moslima, boerka (and Burqa) and Ayaan (and Hirsi).

This article only covers a third of the total research on Opzij (two out of six categories are discussed). All comments in the sample of 36 articles that either dealt with feminism or Muslim women were included in the analysis. If remarks were similar, I selected the quote that best represented the argument.
